Articles.Content:
Can asteroids be destroyed by really fast impacts, or could I airdrop one into Kerbin without a chute and have the asteroid survive (though I think the space agency would get a lawsuit for such reckless behavior)?

**Edited <time datetime="2015-04-07T22:55:51Z" title="04/07/2015 10:55  PM" data-short="9 yr">April 7, 2015</time> by Crusher48**

Probably.

I actually got a small (or medium, I forget the exact size) one down to kerbin, it rolled downhill for a bit and then exploded.

Both as far as I know, if you attach enough chutes it should survive. Also you could fly it to kerbins surface like a ceratin crazy forum member has done as seen

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/WXzMDkKhO5g?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>
.
I believe they will survive a reentry impact but can be destroyed if they're hit really hard.

Asteroids are treated like any other ship part, they have an impact tolerance that, once exceeded, will cause it to blow up. It probably can be destroyed through overheating, too. The tolerances for both are very high, though.
Does anyone know the exact impact tolerance of an asteroid?

You can also destroy asteroids by sending them towards [Kerbol](http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Kerbol#Landing), if the wiki is correct:

> 
> No known way of landing on Kerbol exists, even with all cheats enabled. The overheating effect quickly destroys parts before they can reach the surface. Interestingly, asteroids have a maximum temperature tolerance of 10^38^ so do not overheat even under these circumstances, but are instead destroyed at an altitude of -250 m, which shows in the end flight dialog as "crashed into the surface of the sun" or similar, rather than ever landing.

I also wouldn't be surprised if the asteroids got destroyed deep enough inside Jool.
That maxTemp has got to be unattainable. I guess impact is the only way to break one.
Hard to break but not impossible.
I blew one up with TAC Self Destruct once. ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)
Under current stock aerodynamics, pretty much any asteroid will survive pretty much any fall from orbit to the surface of Kerbin, as long as it lands on land.

> 
> Probably.
> I actually got a small (or medium, I forget the exact size) one down to kerbin, it rolled downhill for a bit and then exploded.

It probably clipped into the ground. ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

CHALLENGE ACCEPTED.

>

> CHALLENGE ACCEPTED.
> 

1e^38^is a really, enormously, huge number. For some perspective, a nice day outside is about 293k.  Water boils at 373k, the temperature at earths core is about 6200k.

Sun's core? a toasty 15 million kelvin, but this is only 0.0000000000000000000000000000001% of the heat tolerance of the asteroid.

OK, so what about Planck's temperature, where it is so hot, quantum physics breaks down because the wavelength of light given off by the particles is the Planck length?

Planck's temperature is 1.417 x 10^32^k. Getting close right?

Wrong

Even at Planck's temp, you are still only 0.000142% of the way there.

Good luck [@doggonemess](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/160106-doggonemess/), you are going to need it.
